GHI Engineering - 16366 // daniel-wachira commented: I believe this is a performance-related problem. The big hint is that these 2 items are true:
1. The kernel notifications queue is filled and overflowing indicating high traffic.
2. Some subnet statistics are collected while others are not.

The logic in collectord behaves like this:
- If we receive a flow, try to attach to a network object id for stats collection.
- If traffic is high and we are not processing the flows fast enough, drop the record. This is done in a loop so some records will be added and others will skip.

A consequence of the above is that if a flow has multiple ids, it will likely not report traffic for all of them and will stop after filling in just enough to fill the queue.

The kernel notifications queue overflow was not being handled correctly before, this is now fixed. We now force-drain the queue if ENOBUFS is reported by the kernel. The buffer sizes on both user and kernel sides is also increased.

Next, I shall review the queue processing to ensure we have no performance bubbles. A lot of internal processing is done with a 10 second timer, but I think we can move some of these out to a separate thread with a shorter interval to ensure resources are correctly utilized.

GHI Engineering - 16366 // daniel-wachira commented: For the KERNELNOTIFICATIONS warnings, I'll prepare a fix. That one is caused by excessive amount of blocked traffic coming through faster than the collector is expecting.

GHI Engineering - 16366 // daniel-wachira commented: @rshawver 
A downgrade will never fix a broken database upgrade. It's less to do with firmware and more to do with database initialization.
What I am curious about is this - what was the initial version installed on the device and what was the initial upgrade done if any?

N/B: There is a known issue going back forever where the manufacture second stage reboot can interrupt database upgrades. This also explains why sometimes after clean install exinda can misbehave and this issue affects every known version of exinda. I did some investigation on this a few months ago and logged the internal ticket https://github.com/trilogy-group/gfi-kanban/issues/2220 for that. A side effect of that is broken monitoring database post-install or upgrade with no simple fix available.

At this point we have:

	* Rebuilt the monitoring database multiple times using the official recovery procedure.
	* Restarted the monitoring services (database, statistics, monitor, datad, JBoss) and rebooted the appliance.
	* Confirmed that some subnets such as DC_INTERNET ITC now report correctly, while others such as Jindal Discovery, Greatship Chetna, and Jagson Sea Challenger still show incomplete data in Monitor → Subnets and in the subnet reports, even though the Realtime monitor clearly shows traffic for those networks.
	* Collected new diagnostics (sysdumps and screenshots) after reproducing these differences side by side.

From the latest diagnostics we can see that the monitoring database and services are running, but the appliance is still logging internal errors in the monitoring stack when processing statistics. This explains why only some subnets are reported correctly and others are not, even though traffic is present.

Because all standard recovery steps have already been applied and the issue is now limited to specific subnets, we have escalated this case to our engineering team for deeper analysis of the monitoring and roll‑up process on your current firmware version. We have provided engineering with:

	* The most recent sysdump taken after the last session.
	* Your screenshots and reports showing Realtime vs Subnets for both working and non‑working sites.
	* The exact time ranges and network objects where the discrepancy occurs.

At this stage we are not planning any further destructive actions (such as clearing the monitoring database again). We are waiting for engineering’s review and guidance on a permanent fix or a safe workaround for the affected subnets.

As soon as we receive their feedback, we will share it with you and, if needed, schedule another session to validate the solution together.

We understand how critical these reports are for your operations and how long you have been dealing with this. Thank you for continuing to work with us while we move this forward with engineering.

Kayako - ticket id 60209095 // Randall Shawver commented publicly: Dear Vaibhav,

Thank you for getting back to us with the examples. 

We reviewed the new sysdump (sysdump-exinda-b080e5-20251223-123052) and the two subnet reports you shared (Fixed_Subnet.pdf and NOT_Fixed_Subnet.pdf) and here’s what we found.

WHAT WE VERIFIED IN THE FILES YOU PROVIDED

	* Monitoring DB rebuild did run / schema is rebuilt

	* In the sysdump mysql.txt, we see: “Initialise database to version 27” (timestamp 2025‑12‑22 21:47:23). This is consistent with the monitoring DB reset activity being executed.
	* We also confirmed there are no “table … doesn’t exist” errors after the rebuild window (post ~22:00 on 12/22 and on 12/23) in the rotated datad logs.

	* Subnet reports are now able to generate data

	* Fixed_Subnet.pdf shows populated conversations for Network “DC_INTERNET ITC”.
	* NOT_Fixed_Subnet.pdf shows populated conversations for Network “Jagson Sea Challenger” (example internal host 10.112.1.67 appears in the report output for the selected time range).
	* This indicates the reporting pipeline can query and return data.

	* What “Jagson Sea Challenger” is configured as

	* In the sysdump configuration, “Jagson Sea Challenger” is a network object (ID 814) defined as 10.112.1.64/28, with subnet reporting enabled.
	* That means the Subnets page/report for this object will only ever show traffic for hosts inside 10.112.1.64/28. If you expect traffic for a broader range, the network object needs to be updated accordingly.

THE KEY NEW ISSUE WE SEE (LIKELY EXPLAINING THE UI BEHAVIOR)

Even though the DB schema is now healthy, the sysdump shows persistent collection-layer errors that can cause monitoring pages (including Subnets) to appear empty or incomplete:

	* In messages we see repeated errors from collectord:

	* KernelNotifications: recvmsg() failed with error: No buffer space available

	* Alongside heavy kernel notifications (setpol notifications: failed to multicast.)

These errors indicate buffer exhaustion / dropped notifications, which can prevent traffic/flows from being fully processed into monitoring datasets even when the DB is functioning.

Recommended next steps

1) CONFIRM “JAGSON SEA CHALLENGER” SUBNET DEFINITION MATCHES WHAT YOU EXPECT

Please confirm: should “Jagson Sea Challenger” cover only 10.112.1.64/28, or should it include more IP ranges?

	* If it should include more, update the network object to include the missing subnet(s), then re-test the Subnets page.

2) REBOOT (TO CLEAR THE BUFFER EXHAUSTION STATE), THEN RE-TEST AFTER 1–2 HOURS

Because collectord is reporting “No buffer space available”, a reboot is a reasonable next step to clear the condition and start with a clean buffer state. After reboot:

	* Wait 3-4 hours
	* Re-test Monitoring → Subnets for “Jagson Sea Challenger” using:
	* Last 10 minutes and Last 1 hour
	* Confirm the traffic source host(s) are inside 10.112.1.64/28 (e.g., 10.112.1.67 is within range).

3)UPGRADE YOUR APPLIANCE TO THE LATEST VERSION

We noticed that you are not using the latest version of Exinda. Updating it could potentially resolve process-related issues and help you take advantage of new fixes.

3) IF THE SUBNETS PAGE STILL SHOWS NO OR INDEQUATE TRAFFIC

Please share a short video that captures the following outcomes:

	* Issue reproduced: Realtime shows traffic for hosts in 10.112.1.64/28, but Monitoring → Subnets → “Jagson Sea Challenger” shows no/incorrect data for that same period.
	* Issue resolved: Monitoring → Subnets → “Jagson Sea Challenger” shows the expected traffic for the same period.
	* My apologies. I recorded our meeting but read.ai reported an error and was unable to save the recording.  Which is why we are requesting new evidence.

With the above, please collect and attach a fresh sysdump immediately after recording the video. We’ll use it to trace the exact traffic shown in the video and determine why it did (or did not) appear in subnet reporting. 

Best regards,
Randall Shawver
GFI - Exinda Network Orchestrator Support Team

RECOMMENDED NEXT STEPS (PLEASE APPLY AGAIN, IN THIS ORDER)

We’d like you to reapply the recovery steps once more, but with one important addition: restart statisticsd, which we did not explicitly ask you to do earlier. This is recommended in the yellow-highlighted footnote in the KB article: error-no-data-available-for-the-selected-period-in-monitoring-graphs [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/118301-error-no-data-available-for-the-selected-period-in-monitoring-graphs]

1) Restart the monitoring-related services

	* From CLI:
	* en
	* conf t
	* service database restart
	* service monitor restart
	* service statistics restart
	* service jboss restart

2) Restart statisticsd and datad process (new step we want you to try)

	* From CLI:
	* en
	* _shell
	* Here's your new Shell Key:  LK2-RESTRICTED_CMDS-45A0-GK0U-B107-5423-KXY8-6GT5-B88Q-YRM6-UTKJ-WKHE-17D6-VCD0-X
	* pm process statisticsd restart
	* pm process datad restart

3) Wait for rollups to catch up

	* Please wait 30 minutes and then re-check:
	* Monitor → Subnets / Applications / Hosts / Users
	* Generate the Subnet report again for Last 24 Hours

4) If still not resolved, re-run the “last resort” database clear steps

	* The same KB above includes the last-resort path (clearing /var/data/monitor and running clear database). If you already ran it before, please consider running it again carefully in the exact sequence described in the KB: https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/118301-error-no-data-available-for-the-selected-period-in-monitoring-graphs

Kayako - ticket id 60209095 // Randall Shawver commented publicly: Hello Sajeedali, Vaibhav, and team,

Thank you for your continued patience and for the detailed information, diagnostics, and screenshots you have shared. I understand this case has been ongoing for a long time and has impacted your operations, and I want to give you a clear, concrete way forward. You may also schedule a meeting at the bottom of this response.

1. WHAT WE CONFIRMED FROM YOUR DIAGNOSTICS

From the diagnostic bundle and the 24‑hour subnet report you provided:

	* The 24‑hour report for network object Jindal_Virtue (26–27 Nov 2025) shows full inbound/outbound conversation data and application details, which confirms that the appliance can collect and report traffic correctly for at least some 24‑hour periods.

	* At the same time, the system log contains many errors like:

	* collectord: KernelNotifications: recvmsg() failed with error: No buffer space available
	* Kernel messages: setpol notifications: failed to multicast.

	* These are known symptoms of the monitoring pipeline (collectord/datad/database) running into resource/buffer problems and failing to roll up data correctly, which leads to blank or partial graphs even when traffic is present. This is the scenario covered by the articles “Monitoring graphs showing data gaps or no data at all” and “The Monitoring Database Has Stopped or Become Corrupted.”[2][1]

This matches exactly what you are seeing: some short/custom windows show data, some 24‑hour ranges work, but other periods (Last 24 Hours, Last 10 Minutes for particular objects) show “Data not available for selected period” even though there was traffic.

2. WHY THE SHELL KEY SHOWED “PERMISSION DENIED”

The “permission denied” error you saw when entering the shell key is caused by where and how it was entered:

	* The restricted shell key is a license string, not a CLI command. If you paste it directly at the exinda-b080e5 # prompt, the system treats it as an invalid command and returns “% Permission denied.”
	* To use the restricted commands (such as pm process ... and direct access to /var/data/monitor), the key must first be installed as a license, either in the Web UI or via the license install command.[5][3]

Please use the newer shell key we sent:
LK2-RESTRICTED_CMDS-45A0-GK0U-B107-5423-KXQ8-6GT4-7U1W-UC6F-UHJ1-QVK6-X1GF-5NHT-R
and apply it using one of the following methods:
Option A – Web UI (recommended)

	* Log in to the Exinda Web UI.
	* Navigate to:
Configuration > System > Setup > License
	* Scroll to the bottom of the page.
	* Paste the above key into the license text area.
	* Click Add Licenses.

Then, in the CLI:

en
_shell

should immediately give you the shell prompt.
Option B – CLI

	* Open a console/SSH session and run:

en
conf t
license install LK2-RESTRICTED_CMDS-45A0-GK0U-B107-5423-KXQ8-6GT4-7U1W-UC6F-UHJ1-QVK6-X1GF-5NHT-R

	* Then:

_shell

to access the shell.
If, after installing the new license, any pm commands still fail, you can remove any old “Restricted commands” license entries from Configuration > System > Setup > License and then re‑install this key, as described in the “Unrecognized command ‘pm’ error” article.[4]

3. STEP‑BY‑STEP CORRECTIVE PLAN

To address the reporting gaps and restore stable subnet/application graphs, the recommended plan is:

STEP 1 – NON‑DESTRUCTIVE MONITORING STACK RESTART

This step does not erase historical data and does not stop traffic forwarding. It may briefly affect the Web UI and reporting while services restart.
From the CLI:

en
conf t
service jboss restart
service datad restart
service collector restart
service database restart

Please run each service command one by one, waiting 1–2 minutes between commands to let each service stop and start cleanly.[1][2]
After all four have been restarted, wait about 10–15 minutes and then check:

	* Monitor > Subnets and Monitor > Traffic Analysis > Conversations
	* For both “Last 10 Minutes” and “Last 24 Hours” views, focusing on objects where you know there is current traffic.

If graphs and tables now populate correctly for those periods, you can stop here.

STEP 2 – MONITORING DATABASE RESET (DESTRUCTIVE; REQUIRES MAINTENANCE WINDOW)

If Step 1 does not resolve the issue, the monitoring database is very likely corrupted, and it must be rebuilt. This will erase historical monitoring data only (traffic stats, flows, old graphs). It will not affect:

	* Device configuration (virtual circuits, policies, objects, VLANs, users, etc.)
	* Live traffic forwarding or optimization, aside from a brief window while services restart.

Before doing this step:

	* Export any critical reports (PDF/CSV) you may need later for audit/compliance.
	* Download a configuration backup from the Web UI.

Then:

	* Install the restricted shell license as described above.
	* Enter the shell and stop MySQL and clear the old monitoring data:

en
_shell
pm process mysqld terminate
cd /var/data/monitor
rm -rf *
exit

	* Back in the CLI, rebuild and restart the monitoring stack:

en
conf t
clear database
pm process mysqld restart
pm process datad restart
pm process collectord restart
pm process monitord restart
pm process jboss restart

Again, run each pm command one by one, with short pauses, to avoid overlapping restarts.[1]
After this, give the appliance 10–15 minutes to rebuild the monitoring database and start populating new data. Then verify that:

	* “Last 10 Minutes” graphs show new traffic.
	* After some time, “Last 24 Hours” starts to show data for periods where traffic is present.

4. ON REMOTE/LIVE ASSISTANCE

I also want to directly address your request for a live SPOC during your maintenance window.
Exinda support for on‑premises appliances is based on a shared responsibility model. We provide:

	* Detailed diagnosis using the files you upload,
	* Documented and tested remediation steps,
	* Clarifications and follow‑up when commands do not behave as expected, but we do not operate your appliance directly or provide guaranteed real‑time, on‑call presence during customer‑scheduled activities.

To make your next window as efficient as possible:

	* Please ensure the shell license is installed ahead of time using the steps above.

	* Plan the activity in two phases:

	* Step 1 (service restarts) first.
	* If graphs remain blank in periods where traffic is present, proceed to Step 2 (database reset) during the same window.

	* If you encounter any specific command errors or unexpected behavior during the procedure, capture the exact CLI output (or a screenshot) and share it in this ticket. We will analyze that output and respond following our support workflow as quickly as we can.

References

	* The Monitoring Database Has Stopped or Become Corrupted [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/117263]
	* Monitoring graphs showing data gaps or no data at all [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/118315]
	* Install a License on an Exinda Appliance [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/121140]
	* Unrecognized command "pm" error [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/121288]
	* Generating a Shell Unlock Key and Activating the Restricted Commands License [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/117786]

Just navigate to the page and pick up a timeslot that suits you.

Kayako - ticket id 60209095 // Carlos Encalada commented publicly: Dear Sajeedali,

Please see below detailed guidance addressing each of your key points and queries:

1. Backup and Restoration of Historical Monitoring Data
Exinda’s configuration backup does not include the monitoring database or historical traffic/reporting data; it only retains system and appliance configuration. The monitoring database contains flow, conversation, and historical reporting data and is stored separately in /var/data/monitor. Exinda does not currently provide a built-in mechanism to export or restore the full raw monitoring database.

Best Practice Before Clearing Data:

	* Manual Report Export: If retaining critical historical data is required, please export essential reports (PDF/CSV) for any necessary period or object before clearing the database. Use the Web UI reporting pages to generate and save these records.
	* No Database Restore Option: Once the clear database and rm -rf * (in /var/data/monitor) procedures are executed, the actual monitoring data is permanently and irretrievably deleted.

2. Impact of Clearing the Monitoring Database
Clearing the monitoring database impacts only the historical monitoring data (traffic statistics, reports, flow/session logs). It does not affect:

	* Device configuration settings (VCs, policies, objects, users, licenses, VLANs, etc.)
	* Live network operation—data path and optimization functions remain unaffected except for the brief window while services restart

Live monitoring and reporting resumes automatically once the appliance completes the service restart and database rebuild—you do not need to reconfigure reporting or monitoring objects. New monitoring data will be collected starting from the point services are restarted.

3. Alternatives to Full Database Reset
There is no officially supported method to partially clean, repair, or selectively preserve historical monitoring data within Exinda. The procedures provided (service restart, then full database clear) are the only remedies for database corruption or persistent rollup failures.

4. Export or Compliance Archiving of Data
The only supported method to “archive” or “export” historical monitoring data for compliance is to:

	* Use the Web UI to generate and download required summary reports (PDF or CSV) for all relevant periods/objects before proceeding with destructive maintenance.

The monitoring database itself is not exportable or restorable via CLI, and is not covered by the regular backup process.

5. Performance Implications If Not Cleared
If you avoid clearing the monitoring database when it is already corrupted, rollup failures and resource exhaustion will continue to cause blank "Last 24 Hours" (and similar) reports. Over time, this may degrade report responsiveness or cause additional system resource warnings, but it will not affect packet forwarding or policies.

6. Automation and Best Practices
There are no officially supported scripts or tools for automating the monitoring database reset in production. The commands must be entered manually, exercising extreme care (as documented in the KB article: The Monitoring Database Has Stopped or Become Corrupted [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/117263-the-monitoring-database-has-stopped-or-become-corrupted]).
Recommended best practices include:

	* Back up current configuration before any action
	* Export essential reports manually as needed
	* Schedule downtime to avoid impact to reporting users (Step 2 only erases monitoring data, not configuration or traffic)
	* Run service restart commands one-by-one, with sufficient pause between them
	* Allow 10–15 minutes for new data to begin populating reports after action is complete

For reference—the step-by-step procedure with risk notes and a demonstration video can be reviewed in the KB article and at this link: https://www.loom.com/share/d343d24f3af44e8196fd6137d67cdcee

		ACTION
		AFFECTED DATA
		CAN BE RESTORED?
		MANUAL EXPORT OPTION

		Configuration backup
		System/VC/Policy config only
		Yes (via backup/restore)
		Not for monitoring data

		Monitoring database clear
		All historical reporting data
		No
		Export PDF/CSV by hand

Please proceed to export any critical reports you may need before clearing the database, as described above. After the procedure, reporting data will accumulate from scratch and previous monitoring history cannot be restored.

If there are further questions about the procedure or its effects, more detailed instructions are available in the Knowledge Base:
The Monitoring Database Has Stopped or Become Corrupted [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/117263-the-monitoring-database-has-stopped-or-become-corrupted]

Best regards,
Carlos Encalada
GFI - Exinda Network Orchestrator Support Team

Kayako - ticket id 60209095 // Carlos Encalada commented publicly: Dear Sajeedali, 

Thank you for your recent follow-up and for thoroughly documenting the issues experienced with blank subnet and application-wise reports on your Exinda appliance running firmware version v7.6.1 (0143). We have analyzed your latest attachments, including both diagnostics files and PDF/graphical reports, to provide a concrete resolution and address your concerns regarding both process and outcome.

Based on the system logs and the observed behavior, your Exinda appliance is experiencing resource exhaustion in background monitoring processes (notably collectord and datad) after the firmware upgrade. This leads to database rollup failures and blank graphs when generating subnet and application reports, especially over larger time ranges (like "Last 24 Hours"), despite traffic being present.

This scenario and the exact errors are covered in Exinda’s official Knowledge Base:

	* The Monitoring Database Has Stopped or Become Corrupted [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/117263-the-monitoring-database-has-stopped-or-become-corrupted]
	* Graphs are not visible in PDF reports for subnets [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/120439]

 
Recommended Corrective Steps (with Cautionary Notes):

	* Restart Monitoring Services (non-destructive):
Enter Exinda CLI and run, pausing for 1–2 minutes between each command:
en
conf t
service jboss restart
service datad restart
service collector restart
service database restart    
   Wait 10–15 minutes after completion for graphs to re-populate. This action should not affect live traffic, but may briefly impact reporting/UI response. 

	* If the problem persists, reset the monitoring database (destructive):
   Warning: This will erase all historical monitoring data. Plan a short maintenance window and back up your configuration beforehand.

   Step-by-step procedure:    

	* In the CLI, enter restricted shell (using the shell key provided previously if prompted):
_shell
	* Stop the monitoring database and remove current stats:
pm process mysqld terminate
cd /var/data/monitor
rm -rf *
exit             
	* Reset and restart all major monitoring services (run each and wait in between):        
conf t
clear database
pm process mysqld restart
pm process datad restart
pm process collectord restart
pm process monitord restart
pm process jboss restart             

It may take up to 15 minutes for the monitoring databases and graphs to repopulate. Please refer to the official KB for screenshots and deeper technical context: https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/117263-the-monitoring-database-has-stopped-or-become-corrupted   

Additional Considerations & Professional Practice:

	* Downtime: Step 2 will temporarily disrupt reporting and will erase all existing monitoring data. Schedule this procedure during a planned outage window.  
	* Backup: Always back up your Exinda configuration before running service restarts or database resets.  
	* Escalation Contacts & Limits: For Exinda on-premises appliances, GFI provides incident resolution through remote diagnosis, published remediation steps, and guidance. Exinda support operates on a shared responsibility model; support cannot directly operate or remotely execute commands on customer appliances. All corrective actions must be applied independently by your team in accordance with our documentation and security controls.  
	* Demonstration Reference: For safe execution, review this short demonstration video (steps applied in a vanilla Exinda test environment):
https://www.loom.com/share/d343d24f3af44e8196fd6137d67cdcee
While the video shows some steps in rapid sequence, in production you should execute commands one at a time to avoid incomplete restarts.
	* Post-Procedure Review: Once complete, monitor your reports to verify that "Last 24 Hours" and similar time-based graphs now populate as expected where there is actual traffic.  

Lastly, please note that we are unable to participate in a remote troubleshooting session unless all documented steps we have provided have been fully completed and you share detailed evidence of the results. If the recommended actions are not carried out, our ability to assist is limited. Should a remote session become genuinely necessary after all troubleshooting options have been exhausted, we will proactively propose it as the next step. 

Best regards,
Carlos Encalada
GFI - Exinda Network Orchestrator Support Team

Kayako - ticket id 60209095 // Syed Haider commented publicly: Dear Sajeedali,

Thank you for getting back to us and for your continued cooperation throughout this case.

The command sequence provided in our last message is the same as the documented procedure outlined in the following Exinda knowledge base article:
🔗The Monitoring Database Has Stopped or Become Corrupted [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/117263-the-monitoring-database-has-stopped-or-become-corrupted]

These technical commands are powerful administrative actions that directly impact the internal monitoring stack (collectord, datad, jboss, and the monitoring database) of the Exinda system. When applied, they can help recover from memory lockups or buffer overflow issues—especially those that arise after firmware upgrades, such as the one currently observed in your v7.6.1 (0143) deployment.

To provide additional assurance, we’ve recorded a short demonstration video of these steps being applied on a clean (vanilla) Exinda system. This showcases the correct order of execution and expected system behavior during recovery: https://www.loom.com/share/d343d24f3af44e8196fd6137d67cdcee

However, I want to highlight an important operational caution. In the demonstration video, for the sake of speed and clarity, I sometimes executed multiple service restart commands quickly or in bulk. For your production environment, we strongly recommend executing each command separately and waiting a short period (1–2 minutes) between each step, as detailed in the official guide. This more careful method helps ensure that each service has fully shut down and restarted properly before proceeding to the next, reducing the risk of cascading errors or incomplete restarts.

In addition, we suggest the following best practices before applying the full reset procedure:

	* 
Plan for a brief downtime window, especially if you move to the database clearing phase (Step 2), which will erase all historical monitoring data.
	* 
Back up your current configuration, allowing for rollback if any issues occur.
	* 
Ensure correct shell key access, particularly if accessing restricted commands.
	* 
Monitor system behavior post-commands, allowing up to 10–15 minutes for graphs and reports to repopulate.

If you have any other questions or concerns, please let us know. To clarify on the previous message, support-assisted walkthroughs or assistance with verifying system readiness before implementing these changes are not covered under the support scope of the shared responsibility model, especially since Exinda is on-premises.

Thank you.

Best regards,
Syed Haider
GFI - Exinda Network Orchestrator Support Team

Kayako - ticket id 60209095 // Syed Haider commented publicly: Dear Sajeedali,

Thank you for providing the diagnostics files. We have analyzed the system logs and identified the cause of the reporting issue.

**Analysis:**
The logs indicate that the `collectord` process is failing to process network traffic due to a buffer overflow error (`No buffer space available`), which often occurs after a firmware upgrade if the monitoring services do not initialize correctly. This prevents data from being aggregated for the "Last 24 Hours" reports.

**Resolution:**
Please follow the steps from our Knowledge Base article: https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/117263-the-monitoring-database-has-stopped-or-become-corrupted

**Step 1: Restart Services (Non-Destructive)**
Run the following commands in the Exinda CLI to fully restart the monitoring stack:

en
conf t
service jboss restart
service datad restart
service collector restart
service database restart

Wait 10-15 minutes and check if the graphs begin to populate.

**Step 2: Reset Database (If Step 1 Fails)**
If the issue persists, the database format may have been corrupted during the upgrade. You will need to clear the current monitoring data to restore functionality.
*Warning: This will remove historical monitoring data.*

1. Enter shell mode:
_shellUse this shell key generated fro your Host ID:  LK2-RESTRICTED_CMDS-45A0-GK0U-B107-5423-KXA8-6GT6-T56X-2V9J-G089-4GTW-NJPQ-X89C-6

2. Stop the database and clear the data:

pm process mysqld terminate
cd /var/data/monitor
rm -rf *
exit

3. Reset the database and restart processes:

conf t
clear database
pm process mysqld restart
pm process datad restart
pm process collectord restart
pm process monitord restart
pm process jboss restart

Please let us know the results.

Best regards,
Syed Haider
GFI - Exinda Network Orchestrator Support Team

Kayako - ticket id 60209095 // ATLAS commented publicly: Dear Sajeedali,

Thank you for your follow-up and for providing additional details and screenshots related to the issue with blank subnet and application-wise reports after your upgrade to firmware version v7.6.1 (0143).

Summary of Findings From Your Attachments:
- In some time ranges (such as “Last 24 Hours” or “Last 10 Minutes”), your Exinda displays “Data not available for selected period” messages for subnet and conversation reports—no graph or data appears.
- However, for specific selected time ranges (for example, 03/Nov/2025 04:00PM – 07:00PM), the same subnet (“Foresight_Driller_9”) correctly shows inbound/outbound activity, application breakdown, and conversation details within the reports.
- When live data is visible for a subnet or network object, all charts and application-wise details are present, confirming that data collection and reporting are functioning within those active periods.

Analysis and Key Points:
- The message “Data not available for selected period” is standard in Exinda and appears only when no traffic is recorded for the object in the selected time window.
- Your screenshots confirm that when data does exist for the subnet and specified range, graphs and application information appear correctly.
- This behavior is in line with normal Exinda operation; there is no evidence of a firmware or reporting engine malfunction.

Possible Reasons for Blank Reports in Certain Periods:
- There was no actual traffic on the monitored subnet(s) during the selected period, even if the network itself was up.
- Reporting might not have been enabled for the object for the entirety of the period selected, resulting in missing data for specific time ranges.
- Network definition or reporting settings may have changed recently; data will only show after enabling the “Reporting” (green checkmark) option.
- Filters or custom selections may limit the view to periods or types of data in which activity was low or not present.

Recommended Steps:

 	* Select Activity Periods: When generating or viewing reports, always choose a time range where you are certain that traffic was present. Your screenshot (03/Nov/2025 04:00PM – 07:00PM) is a good example of such a period and shows populated graphs and application-wise breakdowns.
 	* Check Reporting Settings: Ensure that the “Reporting” option is enabled (as indicated by the green checkmark in the Web UI) for all relevant subnets/network objects. This setting must be active before the reporting period for data to be collected.
 	* Review Filters: Verify that no filters are restricting the dataset (such as by application, host, or traffic type) which might cause a blank result even when some traffic is present.
 	* Special Characters and Firmware: In your firmware version (v7.6.1), issues with special characters in subnet or object names have already been resolved and do not require further action.
 	* Understand Reporting Differences [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/120671]: Scheduled/PDF reports may differ from the interactive Web UI due to backend reporting differences. For the most accurate, live graphical data, use the Web UI and export the PDF directly from there when needed.

Reference Articles:

 	* Graphs are not visible in PDF reports for subnets [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/120439]
 	* Scheduled Reports Look Different Than Some of the Web UI Reporting Graphs [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/120671]

Conclusion:
Your Exinda system is operating as designed: when there is traffic during the selected period, subnet and application-wise reports are populated; when there is none, reports will appear blank or show the “Data not available for selected period” message. If you are certain there was traffic present for a specific subnet/object and time range but the report still shows no data, ensure that the reporting option was enabled throughout the entire period. Otherwise, this is expected system behavior and does not indicate a product fault.

Should you observe missing data in periods where you can verify traffic activity and reporting was enabled throughout, please provide precise details about the subnet/object and time window for further analysis. For general usage, ensuring your time range and reporting options are correctly set will resolve most blank report scenarios.
Sincerely,
Atlas
GFI - Exinda Network Orchestrator Support Team.

What This Indicates:
The fact that data is visible for the same network object over certain periods confirms that your device is successfully collecting and displaying monitoring data; the reporting engine and web UI are functioning for both subnet and application views when data exists.

The “Data not available for selected period” message occurs when no traffic has been recorded for the selected subnet or network object during the specified time range. This is a normal behavior in Exinda reporting. It does not indicate a malfunction of the firmware, the reporting mechanism, or a global issue with application recognition.

Common Scenarios Leading to Blank Reports:

 	* The monitored subnet or network object has no traffic during the selected time period (for example, overnight, maintenance windows, or periods of inactivity).
 	* Filters may be applied (such as focusing on unclassified traffic or narrowing the time range) that exclude existing data.
 	* Network objects may have changed definitions, or reporting may be disabled for selected objects (in your screenshots, reporting appears enabled).

Recommendations:

 	* Ensure the Selected Time Range Contains Active Traffic: 
When viewing or generating reports, choose a time range where you expect network activity for the subnet or network object. As your screenshots demonstrate, selecting the period 03/Nov/2025 04:00PM – 07:00PM produces valid graphs and application data.

Verify that the subnets or network objects you wish to report on have the “Reporting” option enabled (indicated by the green checkmark in the Web UI). You have already confirmed this for at least one object in your attachments. 
 	* Special Characters in Subnet/Object Names: 
In older versions, the presence of special characters in subnet names could disrupt the reports. Since you are on v7.6.1, this issue is resolved, and your objects’ names appear standard, so there is no further action required here. 
Reference: Graphs are not visible in PDF reports for subnets [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/120439] 
 	* Differences Between Web UI and Scheduled/PDF Reports: 
Scheduled reports (or some generated PDFs) might not match the interactive Web UI because of differences in how graphs are generated. For the most accurate, live graphical data, use the interactive Web UI. Manual PDF export from the UI preserves these graphs. More details are available here: 
Reference: Scheduled Reports Look Different Than Some of the Web UI Reporting Graphs [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/120671] 

Conclusion:
Your Exinda device is functioning as expected. The presence of blank graphs for certain periods is due to the absence of data in those specific ranges, not a malfunction of the firmware or system. As long as traffic is present during the chosen time range, subsystem and application-wise reporting should display as intended, as seen in your provided screenshots.

If you encounter blank data where you know traffic exists (for the selected subnet/object and period), consider verifying that reporting has always been enabled and the object's configuration has not changed during that period. For further analysis, ensure that you always select a time range where active traffic has been recently confirmed.

For further reference on reporting behavior and troubleshooting steps, you can review the following Exinda knowledge base articles:

 	* Graphs are not visible in PDF reports for subnets [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/120439]
 	* Scheduled Reports Look Different Than Some of the Web UI Reporting Graphs [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/120671]

If your situation differs—for example, if you observe missing data for periods of confirmed activity, or for all subnet objects and all reports—please specify the network object(s) and period(s) affected so we can assist further.
